title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the northern dusky salamanders found on the hillside in Northern Manhattan?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a rare species found only in the Bronx.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a species that was common in the city 60 years ago but is now stuck on this single hillside and a few places in Staten Island.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a common species found in many areas of New York City.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a species that has been extinct for decades ago.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the white-footed mouse is being used as a model to understand how species are adapting to urban environments?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a species that is easy to catch and study.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a native species that has been here long before humans.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a species that is found in both forested and meadowed areas.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a species that is commonly found in urban environments.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if a single base-pair change in a gene leads to a longer life or more babies for a mouse?

options.label: A
options.text: The change would not spread quickly in an urban population.

options.label: B
options.text: The change would spread quickly in an urban population.

options.label: C
options.text: The change would not affect the mouse's fitness.

options.label: D
options.text: The change would affect the mouse's fitness but would not spread quickly.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Manhattan plot in the context of the lecture?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows the genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows the genetic similarities between city and country mice.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows the genetic changes that occur in mice over time.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows the genetic changes that occur in mice in response to environmental factors.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the urban environment based on the genetic differences between city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: The urban environment is more diverse than the natural environment.

options.label: B
options.text: The urban environment is less diverse than the natural environment.

options.label: C
options.text: The urban environment is similar to the natural environment.

options.label: D
options.text: The urban environment is not affected by genetic differences.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the research being conducted on the white-footed mouse?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how the mouse adapts to its environment.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how the mouse evolves over time.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how the mouse responds to disease.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how the mouse uses energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the research being conducted on the white-footed mouse in the context of urban ecology?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides insight into the genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides insight into the adaptability of the mouse to its environment.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides insight into the evolution of the mouse over time.

options.label: D
options.text: It provides insight into the response of the mouse to disease.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the urban environment based on the fact that the white-footed mouse is found in both forested and meadowed areas?

options.label: A
options.text: The urban environment is diverse and supports a wide range of species.

options.label: B
options.text: The urban environment is not diverse and does not support a wide range of species.

options.label: C
options.text: The urban environment is similar to the natural environment.

options.label: D
options.text: The urban environment is not affected by the presence of the white-footed mouse.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the researchers are sequencing thousands of genes from the white-footed mouse?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how the mouse adapts to its environment.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how the mouse evolves over time.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how the mouse responds to disease.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how the mouse uses energy.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the urban environment based on the fact that the white-footed mouse is found in many areas of New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: The urban environment is diverse and supports a wide range of species.

options.label: B
options.text: The urban environment is not diverse and does not support a wide range of species.

options.label: C
options.text: The urban environment is similar to the natural environment.

options.label: D
options.text: The urban environment is not affected by the presence of the white-footed mouse.

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: Who is the speaker in the transcript?

options.text: A university professor

options.label: B
options.text: A student

options.label: C
options.text: C: A social activist

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: To award financial aid to students

options.label: B
options.text: To expose the financial aid system's oppressive policies and demand change

options.text: To promote education

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Confused and uncertain

options.label: D
options.text: Sarcastic and ironic

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the phrase that Dorothy says instead of the Good Witch's mantra in the story of "The Wizard of Oz"?

options.label: A
options.text: "There's no place like home."

options.label: B
options.text: "No coordinates exist like one's domicile."

options.label: C
options.text: "I want to go home."

options.label: D
options.text: "I'm not from around here."

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, why do ten-dollar words often fail?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are too complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not understood by the audience.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not used in everyday conversation.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not found in the dictionary.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers when it comes to using words?

options.label: A
options.text: To use as many ten-dollar words as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To know their audience and use language that is clear and concise.

options.label: C
options.text: To use vivid descriptors to fill 300 pages.

options.label: D
options.text: To use the same 50 words to fill the pages.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the author's argument about using ten-dollar words?

options.label: A
options.text: That bigger words are always better.

options.label: B
options.text: That ten-dollar words are worthless if they're not understood.

options.label: C
options.text: That novelists should use as many words as possible.

options.label: D
options.text: That brevity is not important in writing.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the most important thing to consider when writing?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of words used.

options.label: B
options.text: The audience's reading level and expectations.

options.label: C
options.text: The length of the text.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of distractions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of using too many ten-dollar words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: The reader will be impressed.

options.label: B
options.text: The reader will be confused.

options.label: C
options.text: The reader will be bored.

options.label: D
options.text: The reader will not understand the message.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for how to use ten-dollar words effectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Use them as often as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Use them sparingly and only when necessary.

options.label: C
options.text: Use them to fill 300 pages.

options.label: D
options.text: Buy a Scrabble board.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the main difference between writing for a novel and writing for a general audience?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of words used.

options.label: B
options.text: The reading level of the audience.

options.label: C
options.text: The length of the text.

options.label: D
options.text: The type of words used.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on the importance of brevity in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not important.

options.label: B
options.text: It is somewhat important.

options.label: C
options.text: It is very important.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most important thing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's final suggestion for how to use ten-dollar words effectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Use them sparingly and only when necessary.

options.label: B
options.text: Use them as often as possible.

options.label: C
options.text: Use them to fill 300 pages.

options.label: D
options.text: Buy a Scrabble board.

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a partnership between two different species, such as bees and flowers?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutualism

options.label: B
options.text: Symbiosis

options.label: C
options.text: Commensalism

options.label: D
options.text: Parasitism

multiple-choice.question: Which bird species is involved in a symbiotic relationship with the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: Clark's nutcracker

options.label: B
options.text: Blue jay

options.label: C
options.text: American robin

options.label: D
options.text: Red-winged blackbird

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the whitebark pine's cones?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide shelter for other plants and animals

options.label: B
options.text: To produce seeds for the Clark's nutcracker

options.label: C
options.text: To feed the forest

options.label: D
options.text: To protect the tree from predators

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers gather seeds from the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: By digging them up from the ground

options.label: B
options.text: By picking them from the cones in the treetop

options.label: C
options.text: By collecting them from the forest floor

options.label: D
options.text: By purchasing them from a store

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Clark's nutcracker storing seeds in a pouch in its throat?

options.label: A
options.text: To cache them in the forest

options.label: B
options.text: To protect them from predators

options.label: C
options.text: To transport them to a new location

options.label: D
options.text: To feed them to its young

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Clark's nutcracker's ability to remember where it caches seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the nutcracker to find food more easily

options.label: B
options.text: It helps the nutcracker to avoid predators

options.label: C
options.text: It ensures the survival of the whitebark pine

options.label: D
options.text: It allows the nutcracker to adapt to changing environments

multiple-choice.question: How have the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine evolved to suit each other in their symbiotic relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: The nutcracker has developed a longer beak, and the whitebark pine has produced more seeds

options.label: B
options.text: The nutcracker has developed a tougher beak, and the whitebark pine has produced cones with easier-to-open seeds

options.label: C
options.text: The nutcracker has developed a more powerful beak, and the whitebark pine has produced cones with more seeds

options.label: D
options.text: The nutcracker has developed a more sensitive beak, and the whitebark pine has produced cones with fewer seeds

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of the symbiotic relationship between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: The nutcracker gets food, and the whitebark pine gets shelter

options.label: B
options.text: The nutcracker gets seeds, and the whitebark pine gets protection from predators

options.label: C
options.text: The nutcracker helps to replant the whitebark pine, and the whitebark pine provides seeds for the nutcracker

options.label: D
options.text: The nutcracker and the whitebark pine both benefit from the relationship

multiple-choice.question: Why is the symbiotic relationship between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine important?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a unique example of symbiosis

options.label: B
options.text: It is an important food source for the nutcracker

options.label: C
options.text: It is crucial for the survival of the whitebark pine

options.label: D
options.text: It is a key factor in the ecosystem

multiple-choice.question: What can be learned from the symbiotic relationship between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of competition in ecosystems

options.label: B
options.text: The significance of symbiosis in ecosystems

options.label: C
options.text: The role of predation in ecosystems

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of human activity on ecosystems

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Clark's nutcracker's behavior of flying through the forest looking for a place to cache seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: To find shelter for the seeds

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid predators

options.label: C
options.text: To cache the seeds in a safe location

options.label: D
options.text: To confuse potential competitors

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers remember where they cache seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They use a mental map

options.label: B
options.text: They use visual landmarks on the landscape

options.label: C
options.text: They use a combination of mental maps and visual landmarks

options.label: D
options.text: They use a sense of smell

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Clark's nutcracker's ability to cache up to 90,000 seeds in the autumn?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the nutcracker to store food for the winter

multiple-choice.question: How have the whitebark pine's branches evolved to suit the Clark's nutcracker?

options.label: C
options.text: The whitebark pine's branches all sweep upwards with the cones at the very ends, so they can offer them to the nutcrackers as they fly by.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of the Clark's nutcracker's ability to remember where it caches seeds?

options.label: C
options.text: It ensures the survival of the whitebark pine
